ygData.msgSnippet: ... Good point.  I think I m confused about how speciation happens.  For some reason, I was under the impression that you assign every specimen to a species

>From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
>
>John, note that one complication in doing this is that you would lose
>the continuity of the species numbers and sizes with current versions
>of NEAT.  What should be done is that species numbers get recorded
>such that they can be restored, and also the compat_thresh needs to be
>remembered in the case of dynamic thresholding.

Good point.  I think I'm confused about how speciation happens.  For some 
reason, I was under the impression that you assign every specimen to a 
species for every generation.  I wasn't aware that anything needed to be 
maintained between generations.  Can you give me a link to a paper that 
discusses speciation in more detail?

>Otherwise, species
>will be renumbered on each generation, and you will forget what your
>threshold is.

What effect does that have?

>So are you saying you intend to write NEAT in Perl or just modify an
>existing NEAT and connect it to Perl?

Either way.  If I can use somebody else's NEAT as a command-line tool, that 
would be my first choice.

>Either way it's an interesting
>idea, but is Perl fast enough to be the main body of NEAT?

Wasn't it you that argued that the NEAT part was usually only a small part 
of the CPU time of an experiment?  So even if it takes two or three times as 
long to generate the next generation of a population, that doesn't add much 
to overall run time, does it?

Perhaps I should ask:  How long DOES it take if, for example, you have a 
fairly large genome and a population of, say, 1000 individuals?  For your 
C++ code, that is.  If it does it in under a second, then I'm sure Perl is 
'fast enough.'  If it takes more like a minute, then it may not be.  What's 
your experience?

-- John
